Christie's announced yesterday that it had approved a $256 million settlement of civil claims that it, along with its archrival, Sotheby's, cheated buyers and sellers as far back as 1992. Forty-eight hours earlier, Sotheby's disclosed that its board approved its half of the $512 million settlement.

Sotheby's former chairman and majority shareholder A. Alfred Taubman is paying $156 million of the auction house's $256 million payment, but Christie's said in a written statement yesterday that it together with its parent company, Christie's International, was coming up with all the money itself.
While Sotheby's is a publicly traded company, Christie's was taken private two years ago when it was bought by Francois Pinault, the French takeover investor, for $1.2 billion.
Both auction houses are able to make $50 million of their payments in the form of certificates issued to clients toward future consignments.

Christie's chief executive, Edward J. Dolman, said the settlement ''will have no impact on our operations,'' yet auction house experts say that the $256 million is bound to affect its financial health. In the three years before it went private, Christie's reported pretax profits of a little more than half of its $256 million payment.
Andree Corroon, a spokeswoman for Christie's, declined to comment on where the auction house will get its financing.

The civil class-action lawsuit grew out of a three-year-old federal antitrust investigation into accusations that top officials of the auction houses colluded on an array of business practices including fixing the prices charged to buyers and sellers.
